awd_titl_txt: SNM: Low-Cost, Large-Scale Nanomanufacturing of Superinsulating Aerogels and Lightweight, Mechanically-Strong Aerogels
awd_abstract_narration:
Heating and cooling of buildings in the United States accounts for 15 percent of energy use and 32 percent of carbon dioxide emissions. Aerogels are low-density, superinsulating nanomaterials that can dramatically reduce these numbers but are expensive to manufacture. While the insulation market is about $40 billion, aerogels account for less than 1 percent of it. Fossil-fuel-based transportation accounts for another 27 percent of emissions. Mechanically-robust aerogels can be used as lighter weight replacements for plastics to reduce the weight of vehicles, improving fuel efficiency by 10 percent. During aerogel manufacturing, supercritical carbon dioxide-based extraction is commonly utilized to remove liquid from a gel while preserving the solid nanostructure of the gel skeleton. This process accounts for as much as 50 percent of manufacturing costs, requires copious amounts of carbon dioxide and energy and stifles throughput. This research award will provide a scientific foundation to enable development and piloting of fast, efficient drying processes that preserve the skeleton of aerogels. It will enable lower costs, scaling of quantities and dimensions and diversification of materials. Porous three-dimensional nanomaterials other than aerogels are pervasive across many fields; for example, artificial tissue scaffolds. Results generated from this research will be relevant to the manufacture of such other nano-scale materials and structures. The work plan includes development of a pre-college STEM curriculum and distribution of public-friendly content about nanotechnology through an online outreach portal.

The enabling technical output is a model of mass transfer in supercritical carbon dioxide under aerogel drying conditions that captures the effects of fluid composition, compressibility and properties and, additionally, material microstructure and strain. This model will enable the determination of modulation of flow rates, temperatures and pressures, select solvents, order pore-fluid exchanges and formulate gels to develop and pilot inexpensive, fast drying processes that minimize macroscopic and nanoscopic damage to aerogels. The technical approach consists of five Tasks. (1) Measure drying kinetics as a function of process parameters to aid in model development and iteratively refine pilot-scale nanomanufacturing; (2) Measure densities of supercritical carbon dioxide-solvent systems and develop metrology to monitor drying; (3) Measure diffusion coefficients; (4) Measure volumetric strain states inside gels in situ as they are dried; and (5) Use small-angle X-ray scattering to elucidate effects of drying on and correlate stresses with morphostructural changes and identify materials for pilot testing. The fundamental nanomanufacturing principles will be applicable to a range of inorganic, polymeric and composite aerogels.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Until recently, synthetic, porous, 3D nanoarchitectures were embodied by only a handful of exotic materials, e.g., silica aerogel used in space or for highly-specialty insulation in heat loss prevention. Today, they're pervasive in numerous fields, e.g., artificial tissue scaffolds, drug delivery systems, and energy storage devices. Many such materials are borne in a solvent, and for the 3D nanostructure to be realized, it must be lyophilized or "released" (dried) from the liquid phase of often complex composition. While lab-scale drying techniques are suitable for production of proofs-of-concept of such materials, scaling up drying while quiescently preserving the intricate nanostructure of these materials is extremely difficult and expensive. Supercritical extraction with CO2 is among the best nanostructure-preserving drying techniques available; however, it is still often accompanied by shrinkage, warping, cracking and/or microstructural changes of the target material due to the solvents swelling and shrinking the material as they change composition through the process. This process is also costly, as it is a batch process requiring high pressure (>100 atm) equipment, so it is essential to maximize throughput to be commercially viable. Industrially, there is not a clear understanding of the physics underlying this extraction process and thus it is generally done empirically and inefficiently. Like porous 3D nanoarchitectures in other fields, aerogels now include a wide variety of compositional configurations tailored for applications beyond the thermal superinsulation compositions. The aerogel community is a thought leader on removing compositionally-diverse liquid-phase components from nanostructured solid-phase systems as it is the critical and cost-driving step in producing monolithic, pulverized and composited aerogels. Realization of the technological promise of porous 3D nanomaterials necessitates fundamental missing knowledge about how to remove solvents from them.


We developed and modeled drying techniques that are scalable, cost-effective, low energy consumption, compatible with disparate solvent and solid-phase systems and minimally alter the microstructure (and macrostructure) of the nanoporous material. While we focused on drying of aerogels, our results are critically relevant to nanomanufacturing of a great number of other materials systems of technological importance.

Specific accomplishments were 1) Highly accurate measurement and modeling of the rate of extraction of alcohol from aerogel during supercritical carbon dioxide drying of it via three redundant and complimentary methods. In particular the models should enable industry to better optimize this process and reduce the cost of their materials going forward. We have also made progress on metrology to measure how dry an aerogel is as it?s being dried for end point detection, i.e., when the process may be stopped.

2) We have very accurately measured densities and viscosities of ethanol-carbon dioxide solutions at supercritical conditions that are essential to model industrial drying of aerogels. During this process, we recognized that data available in the literature are representative of unmixed mixtures.

3) We designed the optical rig to measure Molecular and Soret diffusion coefficients via laser diffraction method. We successfully built parts of the rig, namely: the optics cell, pressure generator, circulation loop, and the CO2 supply. Based on our literature review, our efforts were directed to measure mixture absorption coefficients and refractive indexes as there are almost no published results for absorption coefficient and refractive index for mixtures of Ethanol-CO2 as function of pressure and temperature.

4) We successfully developed the ability to measure 3D strain states in two-photon upshifiting silica aerogel nanocomposites ex situ of the supercritical dryer, i.e., on the bench top. We demonstrated that application of a load to an aerogel sample embedded nanoparticles which absorb infrared light and emit visible light results in a proportional change in brightness of a voxel when illuminated by an infrared laser, allowing for correlation between voxel brightness and localized strain state within the monolith. We demonstrated, for the first time, the ability to directly observe three-dimensional strain states within an aerogel using two-photon upshifting fluorescence nanocomposites and that voxel brightness is linearly proportional to applied load, setting the stage for in situ mechanochemical observations of gels during supercritical drying.

5) We established a fundamental understanding of how the structural nanoscopic rearrangements before and after supercritical drying create stresses that cause shrinkage, compromising the strength of the aerogel monoliths. We found that aerogels that were not aged had dramatic changes in their structure as the shrinkage was up to 20 %, while for gels aged for longer times their shrinkage was about 10%. We have developed a new route to metallic aerogels that bypasses the use of supercritical fluids and handles fragile wet-gel and aerogel precursors. The new method will be exemplified with the synthesis of monolithic carbon and graphitic aerogels from polymer-crosslinked xerogel powders. The new route for the synthesis of carbon aerogels from xerogel powders is expected to speed up solvent exchange processes and bypass supercritical fluid drying, resulting in time, energy, and materials-efficient synthetic methodology.


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Marc Hodes
